doc.field: New terrorist attack on tourists in Egypt

An as yet unknown number of tourists was killed during another terrorist attack in the upper Egyptian town of Luxor. The latest count is 78 victims, including German tourists. According to eyewitness reports, the slaughter went on for about 45 minutes. Initially, the terrorists (presumably Muslim fanatics) attacked a bus carrying Japanese tourists, killing them all with assault rifles. Subsequently they took hold of another bus with French, German and Swiss passengers. Again, all of them were killed. The terrorists are said to have then attacked with daggers further tourists within the temple area. According to Egyptian witnesses, police did not arrive until well after the shooting began. The Egyptian Ministry of the Interior claims all six terrorists were killed, but other reports mention 11 attackers, some of whom were said to have committed suicide.
Bonn: Warning against trips to Egypt
The Foreign Ministry in Bonn warns against trips to Egypt. Major German travel agencies offer rerouting of tourist trips to other spots without additional cost.
Association of Western European Armament meets in Erfurt

The 13 member countries of the Western European Armaments Group WERG intend to intensify their collaboration in the area of designing and producing military hardware. After a WERG meeting in Erfurt, Minister for Defense Volker Ruehe announced that an agency would be set up with the aim of concentrating military production of the participating countries. The goal is to save money and maintain worldwide competitiveness with US suppliers. A basic working plan for the agency is to be worked out over the next twelve months. The meeting preceded a 2-day conference of the Western European Union, during which the foreign and defense ministers of the 28 member countries will mainly discuss closer integration of Western European Union and European Union.
German ministers oppose over-ambitious EU employment policies

Three days before the special European Union summit on employment policy is to begin, the German government again voiced its opposition against over-ambitious aims. In Brussels, federal ministers Waigel, Bluem, and Rexrodt jointly spoke out against fixing rigid aims for improving the labour market. Minister for Economy Rexrodt said the summit meeting had to face reality. Paper, he said, would not produce jobs. Employment policy had to be the responsibility of individual nations. The three German ministers have gone to the Belgian capital to join their colleagues from the other EU countries in laying the groundwork for the summit meeting.
Part-time jobs for the aged regulated by metal and electric sectors

The road has been paved for implementation of part-time jobs for older workers in the metal and electric industrial sectors. Employers and unions agreed to joint formulations regarding the disputed items. One of the points agreed on was the assurance of accumulated overtime bonus payments in case of the employer's bankruptcy. Also, overtime work that occurred previous to the beginning of the part-time status can be included in calculations. The Donaueschingen arbitration conceded the right to part-time work for employees after their 61st birthday. They can work for 2 years and stay homed for the 2 following years, receiving 82% of their last net wages over the course of 4 years. In Baden- Wuerttemberg and North Rhine-Westphalia, slight adaptations will have to be made, because some employees with higher gross wages could receive lower salaries than mandated by law.
Banks demand amnesty for tax-haven seekers

Banks demand an amnesty for tax evaders who transferred funds out of the country. Federal Banking Association's chairman Kohlhaussen declared that a possibly painful reform was necessary so the financial location Germany would be able to compete in the face of hard international competition. Kohlhaussen, who is also spokesman for the Commerzbank's management, calls for an amnesty favoring not only the tax evaders themselves, but also bank officials who had provided them advice and help during the transactions.
Reward posted for Bocholt hostage-taking gangster

The public prosecutor's office in Duisburg has posted a reward of 10,000 marks for information that might help in the search for the man who last Friday committed a bank robbery in Bocholt, stole several cars and took several hostages, later freed. During his flight, he killed a 33- year old man and injured another. He succeeded in fleeing across the Netherlands border, where his trail was lost.
